content.raw: UPDATE: added new ROS APIs that appeared in 2.4.0 and increased many timeouts to allow for the time required to download models when running on a fresh machine.
content.html: UPDATE: added new ROS APIs that appeared in 2.4.0 and increased many timeouts to allow for the time required to download models when running on a fresh machine.

content.raw:
Jenkins two runs results: [first](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/drcsim-any-devel-precise-amd64/1/consoleText) and [second](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/drcsim-any-devel-precise-amd64/2/consoleText)

Most of the Hz problems reported in the issue #206 seems to be fixed, great.

One appeared in the two testing runs:
```
5: [atlas_utils.atlas_hztest_multisense_sl_camera_disparity/test_hz][FAILURE]------
5: average rate (14.671Hz) exceeded minimum (15.000Hz)
...
5: average rate (14.506Hz) exceeded minimum (15.000Hz)
```

In the second run, another two appeared, close to the limit:
```
5: [atlas_utils.atlas_hztest_multisense_sl_camera_points/test_hz][FAILURE]---------
5: average rate (14.953Hz) exceeded minimum (15.000Hz)

5: [atlas_utils.atlas_hztest_multisense_sl_camera_points2/test_hz][FAILURE]--------
5: average rate (14.994Hz) exceeded minimum (15.000Hz)
```

content.raw:
Yeah, that's a tough one.  Those topics are the outputs from stereo processing in `stereo_image_proc`, and the update rate is going to vary from machine to machine, depending on processor specs.  But it will never be higher than the update rate of the input image stream, which in the case of the multisense_sl, is 30Hz.  Given enough CPU cycles, the stereo output rate would be exactly 30Hz in that case.

@_jrivero_  can you update the test parameters until it passes reliably?  I would start by changing the parameters for the multisense_sl `disparity`, `points`, and `points2` topics to:

* `hz`: 20.0
* `hzerror`: 10.0

A similar change will be needed for the `disparity`, `points`, and `points2` topics coming from each pair of hand cameras.  In that case, the input image streams are running at 60Hz, so the stereo outputs won't be any higher than that.
content.html:
Yeah, that's a tough one. Those topics are the outputs from stereo processing in stereo_image_proc, and the update rate is going to vary from machine to machine, depending on processor specs. But it will never be higher than the update rate of the input image stream, which in the case of the multisense_sl, is 30Hz. Given enough CPU cycles, the stereo output rate would be exactly 30Hz in that case.

@jrivero can you update the test parameters until it passes reliably? I would start by changing the parameters for the multisense_sl disparity, points, and points2 topics to:

  • hz: 20.0
  • hzerror: 10.0

A similar change will be needed for the disparity, points, and points2 topics coming from each pair of hand cameras. In that case, the input image streams are running at 60Hz, so the stereo outputs won't be any higher than that.

content.raw:
Ah, @scpeters ran into this problem last week.  This happens when you don't have the ROS `image_transport_plugins` installed.  The ROS image transport system finds compression plugins at runtime and advertises topics based on what's available.  The `rosapi` tests are written to assume that the standard plugins are installed.

I recently added `ros-[fuerte|groovy]-image-transport-plugins` as a dependency in `drcsim-release`.  That probably needs to be added to the Jenkins builds.
content.html:
Ah, @scpeters ran into this problem last week. This happens when you don't have the ROS image_transport_plugins installed. The ROS image transport system finds compression plugins at runtime and advertises topics based on what's available. The rosapi tests are written to assume that the standard plugins are installed.

I recently added ros-[fuerte|groovy]-image-transport-plugins as a dependency in drcsim-release. That probably needs to be added to the Jenkins builds.

content.raw: Added as dependency for drcsim jenkins builds
content.html: Added as dependency for drcsim jenkins builds

content.raw:
We have the performance1.py test also failing. 

@hsu I've changed the [performance factor test](#!/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/196/fix-tests-console-cleanup/diff#chg-ros/atlas_utils/scripts/performance_test1.py) in commit e6d5039 to see what is the real value returned, instead a plain false/true. It looks like the test desired a 0.81 factor while our amazon machine is getting a 0.62 and my local machine something like 0.53. What do you think it would be a good limit to use in the test?
content.html:
We have the performance1.py test also failing.

@hsu I've changed the performance factor test in commit e6d5039 to see what is the real value returned, instead a plain false/true. It looks like the test desired a 0.81 factor while our amazon machine is getting a 0.62 and my local machine something like 0.53. What do you think it would be a good limit to use in the test?

content.raw:
It should be possible, indeed. I would say that it's better to use jenkins infrastructure for this than trying to set up something set up locally, unless you have special interest on running it locally. 

Anyway, we can probably relax the condition to only fail in cases when there is an obvious error.
content.html:
It should be possible, indeed. I would say that it's better to use jenkins infrastructure for this than trying to set up something set up locally, unless you have special interest on running it locally.

Anyway, we can probably relax the condition to only fail in cases when there is an obvious error.

@gerkey I believe we only miss the errors from atlas_sandia_hands_publishers_hz_gpu.test. Problem here are topics related to camera_info and image_raw that, from time to time, fail with the message no messages before timeout.

If there is no error (in my local system works fine) it could be that these topics needs much more time than others to start publishing. In that case, increase the time-limit (240) or wait_time (180) sounds reasonable to you?

It could be something completely different?

content.raw: I was not able to fix all the sandia hand publishers failures after playing with all time related variables in hztest.
content.html: I was not able to fix all the sandia hand publishers failures after playing with all time related variables in hztest.

content.raw: I can reproduce the problem somewhat reliably on my local machine.  Look like the initial subscription to a camera can somehow get lost, which results in `hztest` not receiving any messages.  See pull request #228 for more.
content.html: I can reproduce the problem somewhat reliably on my local machine. Look like the initial subscription to a camera can somehow get lost, which results in hztest not receiving any messages. See pull request #228 for more.

content.raw: Thanks @gerkey . I will relax the performance assertion of the failing test and we should be done as soon as pull request #228 gets merged.
content.html: Thanks @gerkey . I will relax the performance assertion of the failing test and we should be done as soon as pull request #228 gets merged.

content.raw: In 040293e8adcc, I merged from `multicamera_inactive`, which gets the changes in pull request #228.  I now expect the tests to pass, except perhaps for a few places where we need to tweak the expected publication rates.  I'm running the tests locally now.

With these changes, all tests pass for me.
